prompt: <description>**Part 1: Rectangular Metal Plate with Central Circular Hole and Four Perimeter Holes** Begin by creating a new coordinate system with euler angles of 0.0, 0.0, 0.0 and a translation vector of 0.0, 0.0, 0.0. Sketch a rectangle with the following lines: - Line 1: Starting point (0.0, 0.0) and ending point (0.75, 0.0). - Line 2: Starting point (0.75, 0.0) and ending point (0.75, 0.4). - Line 3: Starting point (0.75, 0.4) and ending point (0.0, 0.4). - Line 4: Starting point (0.0, 0.4) and ending point (0.0, 0.0). The rectangle has six loops. Three of these loops are circles with the following centers and radii: - Circle 1: Center (0.075, 0.1) and radius 0.0312. - Circle 2: Center (0.075, 0.3) and radius 0.0312. - Circle 3: Center (0.375, 0.2) and radius 0.175. The other three loops are circles as well, but you need to use arcs to create the gaps for the perimeter holes. Use the same center points and radii as the previous circles, but the arcs should connect the following points: - Arc 1: Starting point (0.75, 0.1) and ending point (0.85, 0.1). - Arc 2: Starting point (0.75, 0.3) and ending point (0.85, 0.3). - Arc 3: Starting point (0.1, 0.2) and ending point (0.0, 0.2). After creating all the curves, loops, and faces, scale the sketch by a factor of 0.75 using the sketch_scale parameter. Transform the scaled 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the euler angles and translation vector from the coordinate system. Extrude the sketch to generate the 3D model with a depth of 0.015 towards the normal and a depth of 0.0 opposite the normal. These extrusion settings, along with the sketch_scale parameter, ensure that the final height of the rectangular metal plate is 0.015.</description>

prompt: <description>Part 1: 3D Model of a Rectangular Prism Construct a 3D model of a rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. The prism has a square base and a square top, with a rectangular side that connects the two. The side is perpendicular to the base and top. 1. Create a new coordinate system with euler angles of [0.0, 0.0, -90.0] and translation vector of [0.0, 0.1275, 0.2991]. 2. Draw a 2D sketch on the X-Y plane of the coordinate system. 3. Create a loop consisting of 4 lines: - Line 1: Start Point at [0.0, 0.0], End Point at [0.2517, 0.0]. - Line 2: Start Point at [0.2517, 0.0], End Point at [0.2517, 0.2283]. - Line 3: Start Point at [0.2517, 0.2283], End Point at [0.0, 0.2283]. - Line 4: Start Point at [0.0, 0.2283], End Point at [0.0, 0.0]. 4. Scale the 2D sketch using a scaling parameter of 0.2517. 5. Transform the scaled 2D sketch into 3D Sketch using the given euler angles and translation vector. 6. Extrude the 2D sketch to generate the 3D model with an extrusion depth of 0.1275 towards the normal, and no extrusion in the opposite direction of the normals. This results in the creation of a new solid body. Part 2: 3D Model of a Cylinder Construct a 3D model of a cylindrical object with a flat top and bottom. The height of the cylinder is approximately three times its diameter. 1. Create a new coordinate system with euler angles of [0.0, 0.0, -90.0] and translation vector of [0.4949, 0.1275, 0.0]. 2. Draw a 2D sketch on the X-Y plane of the coordinate system. 3. Create a loop consisting of a single circle: - Circle: Center at [0.1275, 0.1275], Radius of 0.1275. 4. Scale the 2D sketch using a scaling parameter of 0.2551. 5. Transform the scaled 2D sketch into 3D Sketch using the given euler angles and translation vector. 6. Extrude the 2D sketch to generate the 3D model with an extrusion depth of 0.1275 towards the normal, and no extrusion in the opposite direction of the normals. This results in the creation of a new solid body. Final 3D Model: Cylindrical Object with a Rectangular Hole in the Center The final 3D model is a cylindrical object with a rectangular hole in the center. The cylinder is slightly larger than the hole. The height of the cylinder is approximately three times its diameter, and the height of the rectangular hole is equal to its width. The depth of the rectangular hole is equal to the height of the cylindrical object. Combine the two parts using an appropriate boolean operation (e.g., difference) to create the final 3D model of a cylindrical object with a rectangular hole in the center. The resulting shape should be centered on a white background.</description>

prompt: <description>Part 1 Construct a three-dimensional rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. The sides are parallel and meet at right angles. The dimensions of the sides are equal, and the height is half the length of the sides. Begin by creating a new coordinate system. Set the Euler angles to (0, 0, -90) degrees and the translation vector to (0, 0.0749, 0). Create the first sketch on the X-Y plane. 1. Face 1 a. Loop 1 i. Line 1: (0,0) to (0.749, 0) ii. Line 2: (0.749, 0) to (0.749, 0.749) iii. Line 3: (0.749, 0.749) to (0, 0.749) iv. Line 4: (0, 0.749) to (0, 0) Extrude the sketch along the Z-axis by 0.0749 units. Set the sketch scale to 0.749 and define the `NewBodyFeatureOperation` as the operation. Part 2 Create a second three-dimensional rectangular prism similar to the first one, but this time rotate the first prism so the two share a side. 1. Create a new coordinate system with the following properties: - Euler angles: (-90, 0, -90) degrees - Translation vector: (0.749, 0.0749, 0) 2. Sketch on the X-Z plane. 3. Face 1 a. Loop 1 i. Line 1: (0, 0) to (0.5992, 0) ii. Line 2: (0.5992, 0) to (0.5992, 0.749) iii. Line 3: (0.5992, 0.749) to (0, 0.749) iv. Line 4: (0, 0.749) to (0, 0) 4. Extrusion properties: a. Extrude_depth_towards_normal: 0, as the prism extends opposite to the normal b. Extrude_depth_opposite_normal: 0.0749 c. Sketch_scale: 0.749 d. Operation: `JoinFeatureOperation` The final shape will be described as a three-dimensional rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. The sides are parallel and the top and bottom faces are perpendicular to the sides. The dimensions of the prism are 2 units by 3 units by 4 units, considering the combined prisms from parts 1 and 2.</description>
